questions.text: Temporary and permanent threshold shift are characteristically seen in:
questions.solution:
Noise trauma presents with a temporary and permanent threshold shift on chronic exposure.

Intense sounds manifested as:

  • Temporary threshold shift (TTS): Hearing impaired immediately after exposure but recovers in few minutes to 2 weeks.
  • Permanent threshold shift (PTS): Hearing impairment is permanent and it doesn’t recover at all.

The damage by noise trauma depends on:

  • Frequency of 2000-3000 Hz causes more noise trauma than lower or higher frequencies
  • Increased intensity of noise
  • Continuous noise
  • Pre-existing ear disease

questions.text: Most common location of vocal nodule:
questions.solution:
Vocal nodules:

  • Also known as Singer’s or screamers node.
  • Site- at the junction of anterior one-third, with the posterior two-thirds, as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma.
  • Cause- They are the result of vocal trauma when person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities.
  • They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.

Nodule:

  • Early stages soft, reddish and oedematous swellings
  • Later stages- greyish or white in colour

Symptoms:

  • Hoarseness
  • Vocal fatigue
  • Pain in the neck on prolonged phonation

Treatment:

  • Educating the patient in proper use of voice.
  • Surgery is required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. They are excised with precision.

Fig: Vocale nodules

questions.text: All of the following are true about antrochoanal polyp except?
questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp:

  • Infection is the main etiological factor.
  • It is called as Killian’s polyp.
  • Usually affects children.
  • Site of origin:
    • Mucosa of maxillary antrum
  • C/F
    • Often single, unilateral
    • Hyponasal voice (Rhinolalia Clausa)
  • O/E:
    • Since it grows posteriorly, it is missed on anterior rhinoscopy.
    • Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana or the nasopharynx.
    • It is soft, it can be moved up and down.
  • Investigation of choice:
    •  NCCT
  • Treatment of choice:
    • FESS

questions.text: Type of hearing loss in Otosclerosis seen often is:
questions.solution:
Hearing loss is the presenting symptom in Otosclerosis. It is often bilateral conductive type.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replaces part of normally dense enchondral layer of bony otic capsule.

Most often, otosclerotic focus involves the stapes region leading to stapes fixation and conductive deafness.

Types of Otosclerosis:

  • Stapedial Otosclerosis: Conductive deafness is the most common variety.
  • Cochlear Otosclerosis: May cause sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Histologic Otosclerosis: Remains asymptomatic and causes neither conductive nor sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Apple-jelly nodules on the nasal septum are found in case of__________
questions.solution:
Apple jelly nodules are seen in Lupus vulgaris.

Lupus vulgaris: It is a low-grade tuberculous infection commonly affecting nasal vestibule or the skin of nose and face.

Manifestations - The skin lesions manifest characteristically as brown, gelatinous nodules called “apple-jelly” nodules. In the vestibule it presents as chronic vestibulitis. Perforation of cartilaginous part can occur.

Investigation - Biopsy of the lesion

Treatment - Anti tubercular drugs

questions.text: The gold standard imaging modality for diagnosis of Vestibular Schwannoma is:
questions.solution:
The gold standard for diagnosis of Vestibular Schwannoma is MRI with Gadolinium.

Acoustic neuroma/ Vestibular Schwannoma/ Neurilemmoma/ Eighth nerve tumour:

  • It is a benign, non-encapsulated and extremely slow-growing tumour of the VIIIth nerve.

MRI with gadolinium contrast:

  • It is superior to CT scan and is the gold standard for diagnosis of acoustic neuroma.
  • Intracanalicular tumour of even a few millimetres, can be easily diagnosed by this method.

questions.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by _________
questions.solution:
Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by Epstein barr virus.

WHO defined leukoplakia as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. 

Other white lesions of oral mucosa:

  • Lichen planus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus
  • White spongy nevus
  • Candidiasis

questions.text: Gelle's test was done to diagnose ________
questions.solution:
Gelle’s test was done to diagnose stapes fixation in Otosclerosis but has now been superseded by Tympanometry.

Gelle's Test: It tests the effect of increased air pressure in ear canal on hearing.The increase in air pressure using siegel's speculum decreases hearing by reducing mobility of tympanic membrane and ossicles and immobility of basilar membrane.

  • Positive Gelle's:
    • Normal individuals
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Negative Gelle's: When ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected(Otosclerosis)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about infant larynx?

choices.text: Epiglottis is soft and omega shaped
Larynx positioned at the level of C2-C3
Supra glottis is the narrowest part

questions.solution:
Subglottis(not supraglottis) is the narrowest part of infant larynx.

Differences between larynx in infants and adults:

Feature  Infants  Adults 
Position  Opposite C2,C3  Opposite C3-C6 
Epiglottis  Large, omega shaped  Leaf shaped 
Thyroid cartilage  Flat  Angulated 
Larynx  Inverted conical or funnel shaped  Cylindrical 
Narrowest part  Subglottis  Glottis 
Submucosal tissue  More and loose  Less and dense 
Laryngeal cartilages  Soft and collapsible  Ossified and hard

questions.text: Malignant Otitis Externa is______
questions.solution:
Malignant Otitis Externa/ necrotizing Otitis Externa is an infective and locally invasive condition.

It is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in immunocompromised individuals like elderly, diabetics, patients on immunosuppressants and steroids.

It presents as severe ear pain with discharge.

Diagnosis:

  • Biopsy to exclude carcinoma.
  • Tc 99 scan helps in early diagnosis before radiological changes appear.
  • Gallium citrate 67 scan, Indium 111 labeled leukocyte scan are used to test resolution of infection.
  • MRI to see intracranial spread and CT scan to detect bone erosion.

Treatment:

  • Antipseudomonal antibiotics, debridement of necrotic material.

questions.text: The following is not a part of the triad of Melkersson syndrome:
questions.solution:
Vesicles in Pinna is not a part of the triad of Melkersson syndrome.

Melkersson Rosenthal Syndrome: It consists of a triad of

  • Facial paralysis
  • Swelling of lips
  • Fissured tongue

It is an idiopathic disorder. The facial paralysis may be recurrent. Treatment is the same as for Bell palsy.

questions.text: Most common post-operative complication of Tonsillectomy is:
questions.solution:
Most common complication of tonsillectomy is hemorrhage.

It is most commonly venous in origin, from the paratonsillar/ external palatine vein.

Torrential haemorrhage can be due to injury to aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of facial artery.

Blood supply

Arterial supply:

  • Tonsillar branch of facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of facial artery.
  • Ascending pharyngeal branch of external carotid artery.
  • Dorsal lingual branches of lingual artery.
  • Descending palatine branches of maxillary artery.

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

Types of Hemorrhage:

  • Primary hemorrhage:
    • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
    • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage:
    • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
    • It may be due to dislodgement of clot, slippage of ligature or return of blood pressure to normal.
    • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
    • If not controlled patient is anaesthetized and haemorrhage managed by re-exploration.
  • Secondary hemorrhage:
    • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th post operative day).
    • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of membrane.
    • Patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: Best X-ray view for frontal sinus is ______
questions.solution:
Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is the best xray view for frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

 

Towne's view: anteroposterior radiographic projection devised to demonstrate the occipital bone, foramen magnum, dorsum sellae as well as petrous ridges.

Water's view: also known as ocipitomental view is a radigraphic view where an X ray beam is angled at 45 degree to the orbitomeatal line. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of skull principally used for viewing mastoid cells.

questions.text: Pathognomonic feature of Maxillary sinusitis is:
questions.solution:
Anterior rhinoscopy in chronic maxillary sinusitis shows discharge in middle meatus which is mucoid or mucopurulent.

Symptoms of Maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain mainly over upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing.
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise, fever.
  • Headache in frontal region.
  • Nasal and post nasal discharge.
  • Redness and edema of cheeks.
  • Tenderness on pressing over anterior wall of antrum.
  • Investigation- Transillumination test and water’s view
  • Treatment- Antimicrobial drugs and antral lavage

questions.text: Jugular bulb is related to which part of the tympanic cavity?
questions.solution:
The floor of middle ear is a thin plate of bone, which separates tympanic cavity from the jugular bulb.

Floor is formed by thin plate of bone separating it from the jugular bulb below. It can be congenitally deficient and jugular bulb is separated from middle ear only by mucosa.

questions.text: Typical delta sign on contrast enhanced CT is seen in:
questions.solution:
Typical delta sign on contrast-enhanced CT is seen in Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis (Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis).

Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis:

  • It is an inflammation of the inner wall of lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.
  • It occurs as a complication of acute coalescent Mastoiditis, masked Mastoiditis or Chronic Suppuration of Middle ear and Cholesteatoma.

Investigations:

  • Blood culture to find out causative organisms.
  • CSF analysis is normal except increased CSF pressure and helps ruling out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign:
    • It is a triangular area with rim enhancement and the central low-density area is seen in the posterior cranial fossa on axial cuts.
    • MR venography is useful to assess progression or resolution of thrombus.

Image showing a filling defect (thrombus) outlined by contrast medium in the sigmoid sinus. This “empty triangle” is the delta sign.

questions.text: Mucocele is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are:

  • Frontal (MC)
  • Ethmoidal
  • Maxillary
  • Sphenoidal

questions.text: True regarding facial nerve paralysis associated with transverse fracture of temporal bone:

choices.text: Incidence less common than longitudinal fracture
Nerve injured proximal to geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
Facial palsy is seen more often in transverse fractures (50%) than longitudinal fractures (20%).

Transverse fracture runs across the axis of the petrous bone. There is injury to nerve in meatal or labyrinthine segment proximal to geniculate ganglion.

Logitudinal fracture v/s transverse fracture:

Features   Longitudinal fracture Transverse fracture
Frequency of fracture (do not confuse with nerve palsy) More common (80%)   Less common (20%) 
Type of injury     Parietal blow  Occipital blow 
Fracture line Runs parallel to long axis of petrous pyramid  Runs across the petrous. 
Bleeding from ear    Common, due to injury to tegmen and  tympanic membrane  Absent because tympanic membrane is intact 
Cerebrospinal fluid otorrhea    Present, often mixed with blood   Absent or unmanifested 
Structures injured   Tegmen, ossicles and tympanic membrane   Labyrinth or CN VIII  
Hearing loss    Conductive  Sensorineural  
Vertigo    Less often; due to concussion  Severe, due to injury to labyrinth or CN VIII 
Facial paralysis    Less (20%), delayed onset. Nerve is injured in  tympanic segment, distal to geniculate ganglion  Most common (50%). Immediate onset. Injury to nerve in meatal or labyrinthine segment proximal to geniculate ganglion.

questions.text: Respiratory papillomatosis is caused by?
questions.solution:
Respiratory or juvenile papillomatosis is caused by HPV.

Respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is a type of squamous papilloma of larynx.
  • It is viral in origin caused by human papilloma DNA virus type 6 and 11.
  • Children who had tracheostomy for respiratory distress due to laryngeal papillomas have higher incidence of tracheal and stomal involvement due to seeding.
  • DNA of virus particles found in the cells of basement membrane of respiratory mucosa account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Features: Child presents with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or stridor.
  • Diagnosis: Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy and confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Treatment: Microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament.
  • Investigational treatments: interferon alpha-2a, carbinol, acyclovir and 13-cis-retinoic acid but have several side effects.
  • Others : Cidofovir (post resection), Bevacizumab (adjunct to debulking)
  • Prognosis: Recurrence is common and procedure needs to be repeated several times.
  • Rarely undergo malignant change.

questions.text: Para pharyngeal space extends from________

choices.text: Base of skull to bifurcation of Trachea
Base of skull to the level of hard palate
Base of skull to level of C7 vertebra
Base of skull to hyoid bone

questions.solution:
Para pharyngeal space extends from base of skull to hyoid bone.

Parapharyngeal space: It is pyramidal in shape with its base at the base of skull and its apex at the hyoid bone.

Relations:

  • Medially: Buccopharyngeal fascia covering the constrictor muscles.
  • Posterior: Prevertebral fascia covering prevertebral muscles and transverse processes of cervical vertebrae.
  • Lateral: Medial pterygoid muscle, mandible and deep surface of parotid gland.

Contents:

  • Anterior/pre-styloid compartment:
    • Maxillary artery
    • Mandibular nerve branches
  • Posterior/post-styloid compartment:
    • Internal carotid artery
    • Internal jugular vein
    • Cranial nerves 9, 10, 11, 12
    • Cervical sympathetic trunk

questions.text: Mouse nibbled appearance of the vocal cord is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ulceration of vocal cord giving mouse-nibbled appearance is seen in Tuberculosis of the larynx.

Tuberculosis of the larynx:

  • Mostly affecting males in the middle age group.
  • Cause - secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis
  • Posterior part of larynx more affected than anterior.

Parts affected in the order of involvement are:

  • Interarytenoid fold
  • Ventricular bands
  • Vocal cords
  • Epiglottis

Symptoms:

  • The weakness of voice is the earliest symptom followed by hoarseness.
  • Severe pain which may radiate to the ears.
  • Swallowing is painful with marked dysphagia in later stages.

Laryngeal examination:

  • Hyperaemia of the vocal cord with impairment of adduction is the first sign.
  • Swelling in the inter arytenoid region giving a mamillated appearance.
  • Ulceration of vocal cord giving a mouse-nibbled appearance.
  • Superficial ragged ulceration and granulation tissue on the arytenoids and interarytenoid region.
  • Pseudoedema of the epiglottis-turban epiglottis.
  • Swelling of ventricular bands and aryepiglottic folds.
  • Marked pallor of surrounding mucosa.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest Xray and sputum examination
  • Biopsy of laryngeal lesion is essential to exclude carcinoma

Treatment:

  • Anti tubercular drugs and voice rest.

questions.text: The most common malignancy of the nasal cavity is?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy of the nasal cavity is Squamous cell carcinoma which is seen in about 80% of cases. 

Primary carcinoma of the nasal cavity is rare. Usually, it is an extension of maxillary or ethmoid carcinoma.

Adenoid and adenocystic are the other types of nasal carcinoma.

questions.text: Which is known as artery of epistaxis?

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.solution: Majority of blood supply to the nasal cavity is by the sphenopalatine artery and is the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis. Hence this is called the artery of epistaxis.

questions.text: The following are characteristic features of SNHL except:
questions.solution:
In Sensori Neural Hearing Loss (SNHL)

  • Air-bone gap in audiometry is less than 15-20 dB.
  • Rinne's test: Positive when AC more than BC.
  • Weber's test: Lateralized to better ear
  • Speech discrimination : Reduced in cochlear lesions (sensory), very poor in retro-cochlear (neural) lesions.
  • ABC: Shortened as compared to examiner's.
  • Shwabach: Sshortened as compared to examiner's.
  • Bing test: Louder (when occluded)
  • Gelle's test: Positive Gelle's test in SNHL. Decreased hearing after increasing pressure.

questions.text: Surfer's ear is______
questions.solution:
Surfer's ear is exostoses.

Exostoses: They are the most common benign tumour of the EAC. They are bilateral, multiple, sessile bony swellings in the deeper (medial) part of bony EAC. They occur due to reactive bone formation in response to exposure to cold water and hence called Surfer's ear. If it is large, it can cause conductive hearing loss. If symptomatic it can be removed by a drill.

questions.text: Type 1 thyroplasty is used for:
questions.solution:
Thyroplasty:

It is a form of phono-surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki divided thyroplasty procedures into four categories to produce functional alteration of vocal cords.

  • Type 1- Medialisation of vocal cord.
  • Type 2- Lateralisation of vocal cord to improve the airway.
  • Type 3- Shortening of vocal cord. This gives low pitch voice. Done in puberphonia and in those who have undergone transformation from female to male.
  • Type 4- Lengthening of vocal cord. This gives high pitch voice. Done in androphonia, conversion from male to female and age related laxity of vocal cord.

questions.text: What is the source of epistaxis after the ligation of the external carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Ethmoidal artery is a branch of ophthalmic division of Internal Carotid artery, so it will be the source of epistaxis after the ligation of external carotid artery.

Blood supply of nose:

  • It is from branches of Internal and External Carotid artery.
  • So in cases of ligation of external carotid artery, the source of bleeding is from branches of Internal Carotid artery.
  • Branches of internal carotid artery supplying nose includes anterior and posterior Ethmoidal artery.

Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external Ethmoid (Lynch) incision.

questions.text: Decompression surgery of Endolymphatic sac is the treatment for?
questions.solution:
Decompression of endolymphatic sac is one of the conservative procedures used in the surgical management of Meniere's disease.

Surgical treatment of Meniere's disease:

  • Conservative procedures:
    • Decompression of endolymphatic sac
    • Endolymphatic shunt operation
    • Sacculotomy (Fick’s operation)
    • Section of vestibular nerve
    • Ultrasonic destruction of vestibular labyrinth
  • Destructive procedure:
    • Labyrinthectomy
  • Intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy (Meniett device therapy)

questions.text: Which of the following nasal tumours originates from the olfactory mucosa?
questions.solution:
Esthesioneuroblastoma:

  • Olfactory neuroblastoma/olfactory placode tumour.
  • It arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of nose.
  • Bimodal peaks of incidence is seen.
  • Neck lymph node metastasis and invasion of orbit may be seen.
  • Symptoms- U/L nasal obstruction and epistaxis.
  • O/E- Cherry red friable polypoidal mass in the upper third of the nasal cavity and is vascular.
  • Investigations- HRCT and MRI with enhancement.
  • Treatment- Cranio facial resection by Osteoplastic flap with adjuvant preop chemo/ radiotherapy.

questions.text: Thornwaldt's disease is ______

choices.text: Abscess formation in fossa of Rosenmuller

questions.solution:
Thornwaldt's bursitis/ Nasopharyngeal bursitis is the infection of thornwaldt's bursa(nasopharyngeal bursa) which is a remnant of notochord, present as a median recess at the junction of roof and posterior wall of nasopharynx.

Clinical features:

  • Persistent post nasal discharge with crusting
  • Nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction and serous otitis media
  • Dull occipital headache
  • Sore throat
  • Fever

Management:

  • Antibiotics
  • Marsupialisation or cyst excision by transpalatal route if cyst or abscess develops

questions.text: Cricothyroid muscle is supplied by:
questions.solution:
Motor nerve supply of larynx:

  • All the muscles which move the vocal cord are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except the Cricothyroid which is supplied by the external laryngeal branch of superior laryngeal nerve.

Sensory nerve supply of larynx:

  • Above the vocal cord- Superior laryngeal nerve
  • Below the vocal cord- Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course hence it is more prone for paralysis than its counterpart.

questions.text: Ear protectors can give protection from noise intensity up to _______
questions.solution:
Ear protectors or ear muffs give noise protection from intensity of 30-40 dB. Hence, the most appropriate answer in the options is 35 dB.

Hearing attenuation provided by different devices:

Device   Hearing attenuation  
Cotton wool  5 dB 
Ear plug   15-30 dB
Ear muffs  30-40 dB
Ear plugs + muffs  More than 40 dB

 

Factories act 1948: Permissible exposure in cases of continuous noise or a number of short-term exposures.

Noise level (dB)  Permitted hours of exposure/day 
90  8 
92  6 
95  4 
97  3 
100  2 
102  1.5 
105  1 
110  0.5 
115  0.25

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of a hypernasal voice. In which of the following conditions will this not be expected?
questions.solution:
A hypernasal voice is known as rhinolalia aperta, and it will not be expected in adenoids. 

Adenoids cause blockage of the nose or nasal cavity, leading to a change in a voice called rhinolalia clausa. 

Rhinolalia aperta is also known as hypernasality of voice. This is caused due to failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities. It is seen when certain words that have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. 

Causes of rhinolalia aperta include velopharyngeal insufficiency, congenitally short soft palate, large nasopharynx, cleft or paralysis of the soft palate, post-adenoidectomy, and oro-nasal fistula.

Rhinolalia clausa/closed rhinolalia is characterized by hyponasality of voice. This implies reduced or absence of normal resonance of nasal consonants 'm', 'n', 'ng' etc. This finding is due to the obstruction in the nasal cavity or nasopharynx. 

Causes of rhinolalia clausa include common cold, nasal allergy, nasal polypi, adenoids, and nasopharyngeal mass.

questions.text: Killian’s incision is used for_______
questions.solution:
Killian’s incision is used in submucous resection. It is given 1.25cm behind the columella at the mucocutaneous junction at the convex side of deflection.

Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is given at the caudal end of the septum, usually on the concave side of the cartilage.

questions.text: A patient with a history of foul-smelling ear discharge, for which he did not complete treatment now presents with complaints of fever with chills and swelling over the mastoid. On examination, there is tenderness along the jugular vein. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.

Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis:

  • Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. The clinical picture resembles malaria but lacks regularity.
  • Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to peri-sinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction.
  • Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.
  • Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. It is often seen with the right sinus (which is larger than the left).
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein. There may be associated enlargement and inflammation of the jugular chain of lymph nodes and torticollis.

Investigations:

  • Blood culture 
  • CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows:
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign.

 

Treatment:

  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
  • Ligation of internal jugular vein
  • Anticoagulant therapy

questions.text: Mechanism of injury in Chevallet fracture is:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of injury in Chevallet fracture is blow from side.

Chevallet- A Chevallet fracture is a Class 1 fracture of nasal septum. The mechanism of injury is a blow from side. The fracture line is vertical extending from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of bony and cartilaginous dorsum of nose.

Jarjaway- A Jarjaway fracture is a class 2 fracture, and it results from a blow from the front or side. A frontal impact tends to comminute the nasal bones and cause gross flattening and widening of the dorsum, while a lateral impact produces a high deviation of the nasal skeleton. The perpendicular plate of ethmoid is also involved and it results in a characteristically C shaped fracture. 

Note: Mechanism of injury in Chevallet fracture is a controversial topic. According to some authors (Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat 6th Edition by Dhingra), Chevallet fracture results from a blow from below. But lateral force is the preferred answer according to other standard textbooks of ENT.

questions.text: B/L recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy is seen in
questions.solution:
B/L RLN palsy Right RLN Palsy Left RLN Palsy
Thyroidectomy Neck trauma

Neck:

Neck trauma
Carcinoma thyroid Benign or malignant Thyroid disease Benign or malignant Thyroid disease
Cancer cervical oesophagus Thyroidectomy Thyroidectomy
Cervical lymphadenopathy Cancer cervical oesophagus Cancer cervical oesophagus
  Cervical lymphadenopathy Cervical lymphadenopathy
  Carcinoma apex of right lung Mediastinum:
Bronchogenic carcinoma
  TB of cervical pleura  Cancer of thoracic oesophagus
  Idiopathic Aortic aneurysm
  Aneurysm of Subclavian artery Mediastinal lymphadenopathy
    Enlarged left auricle
    Intrathoracic surgery
    Idiopathic

questions.text: Rhinophyma is associated with_____
questions.solution:
Rhinophyma:

  • It is also called as potato tumour.
  • It is a slow-growing benign tumour.
  • It is due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of nose often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea.
  • It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation.
  • It mostly affects men past middle age.

Features:

  • Unsightly appearance of the tumour.
  • Obstruction to breathing and vision due to large size of the tumour.

Treatment:

  • Reduce the bulk of tumour with sharp knife or carbon dioxide laser and the area allowed to re-epithelialize.
  • Complete excision and the raw area skin grafted.

questions.text: Chromosome involved in Meniere's disease is:
questions.solution:
Chromosome involved in Meniere's disease is short arm of chromosome 6.

Meniere’s disease can occur due to autoimmune, trauma, viral infections, hypothyroidism, sodium and water retention, and other causes. Most cases are sporadic. Family history is seen in 10-15% cases. 

Note: No convincing evidence for the association of Meniere's disease with a specific gene has been found, at present. The findings in the literatures indicate a genetic heterogeneity.

questions.text: Holman Miller sign is pathognomonic of_____
questions.solution:
The antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal fibroma/ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare tumour, though it is the commonest of all benign tumours of nasopharynx. It is made up of vascular and fibrous tissue hence account for the severe bleeding.

The diagnosis is mostly based on clinical picture and the biopsy of the tumour is avoided.

  • CECT is the investigation of choice. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus, often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.
  • MRI for intracranial extension or extension into orbit or infratemporal fossa.
  • Carotid angiography to know vascularity and feeding vessel for preoperative embolization.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Hennebert's sign is seen in ________
questions.solution:
Hennebert's sign is a positive fistula sign in the absence of a fistula seen in congenital syphilis due to formation of adhesions between stapes footplate and saccule.

This is not to be confused with Hennebert's phenomenon which is disequilibrium following nose blowing or lifting a heavy object. It is seen in perilymph fistula.

questions.text: Phelp's sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Phelp's sign is seen in Glomus tumour which is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and cause aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

Investigations:

  • Phelp's sign on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumour by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives soft tissue extent of tumour.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when CT head shows involvement of jugular bulb, carotid artery or intradural extension.
  • Biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumour.

questions.text: Bony septal perforation occurs in:
questions.solution:
Syphilis involves perforation of the bony and cartilaginous part.  Lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy cause perforation only in the cartilaginous part.

Septal perforation can be caused by:

  • Trauma
  • Pathological:
    • Septal abscess
    • Nasal myiasis
    • Rhinolith
    • Chronic granulomatous disease
    • Wegner's granulomatous disease
  • Drug-related:
    • Chronic use of steroid spray
    • Cocaine abuse
    • Arsenic/ chromium
  • Idiopathic

questions.text: Oort's anastomosis is_______

choices.text: Labyrinthine and anterior inferior cerebellar artery anastomosis
Occipital and posterior auricular artery anastomosis

questions.solution:
Oort's anastomosis is vestibulo-cochlear nerve anastomosis.

Anastomosis of Oort is located at the bottom of the internal auditory meatus and links the saccular nerve to the cochlear nerve. The vestibulocochlear anastomosis could be the pathway for the nerve fibers of the cochlear efferent system.

questions.text: All these structures are seen in the lateral nasal wall except?
questions.solution:
Vomer bone is seen in the medial wall or septum of nose (not lateral wall).

The structures forming the lateral wall of nose include:

  • Superior turbinate and meatus
  • Middle turbinate and meatus
  • Inferior turbinate and meatus
  • Spheno-ethmoid recess
  • Agger nasi
  • Hasner’s valve- This mucosal valve guards the opening of the Nasolacrimal duct in the inferior meatus of the lateral wall.

Structure forming the nasal septum include:

  • Columellar septum
  • Membranous septum
  • Septum proper:
    • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
    • Vomer
    • Large septal cartilage
    • Crest of nasal bones
    • Nasal spine of frontal bone
    • Rostrum of sphenoid
    • Crest of palatine bones
    • Crest of maxilla
    • Anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: Multiple perforations of pars tensa is characteristic of
questions.solution:
Multiple perforations in the pars tensa is characteristic of Tuberculosis of the ear

Tuberculosis of ear:

  • Usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

Pathology:

  • Submucosal tubercles in middle ear cleft, necrosis of tympanic membrane.

Clinical features:

  • Painless condition
  • Foul smelling discharge from ear
  • Multiple perforations in pars tensa of tympanic membrane
  • Pale granulations in middle ear cleft

Complications:

  • Facial nerve palsy (most common)
  • Mastoiditis
  • Postauricular fistula
  • Osteomyelitis

Treatment:

  • ATT
  • Aural toilet
  • Treatment of secondary infection
  • Mastoid surgery for complications

questions.text: Turbinate which articulates with the ethmoid bone is_________
questions.solution: Inferior turbinate is a separate bone and articulates with ethmoid whereas superior and middle turbinates are part of ethmoid bone.

questions.text: Best graft for myringoplasty is:
questions.solution:
Temporalis fascia is the most common graft material used.

Closure of perforation of pars tensa of the tympanic membrane is called myringoplasty.

Graft materials used in tympanoplasty are:

  • Temporalis fascia (most common)
  • Areolar fascia overlying the temporal fascia
  • Perichondrium from the tragus
  • Cartilage
  • Vein
  • Periosteum

questions.text: Direction of Nasolacrimal duct is:
questions.solution:
Direction of the NLD is downwards, backwards and laterally.

Nasolacrimal duct:

  • It extends from neck of the lacrimal sac to inferior meatus of the nose.
  • It is about 15-18 mm long and lies in a bony canal formed by the maxilla and the inferior turbinate.
  • Direction of the NLD is downwards, backwards and laterally.
  • Externally, its location is represented by a line joining inner canthus to the ala of nose.
  • The narrowest part of the NLD- upper end.
  • The Valve of Hasner is present at the lower end of the duct prevents reflux from the nose.

questions.text: The sign in the image given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries - Lyre’s sign

Carotid body tumour:

  • It arises from the chemoreceptor cells in the carotid body, hence called chemodectoma.
  • Mostly presents after 40 years.
  • It is a very slow-growing tumour.

Features:

  • Painless swelling which is pulsatile.
  • Bruit can be heard with a stethoscope.
  • It moves from side to side but not vertically.
  • It may extend into the parapharyngeal space and present in the oropharynx.
  • Some tumours are functional and secrete catecholamines.

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI with gadolinium are diagnostic and also show the extent of the tumour. MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries (Lyre’s sign). Serum catecholamines and urinary meta-nephrines and vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) should be estimated.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or biopsy should not be done because of the vascularity of tumour.
